author: merkalK
title: Pirates watch out!
review: Here are the Vikings! Finally the first good historic ship after Black Sea Barracuda. The serpent is the coolest creature in the Viking line. The ship can easily to modified into a freighter or maybe even a prison ship for the Fenris wolf in 7015.

author: Lizardking
title: The Longships are coming!
review:
After many disappointing castle sets, the new viking series is just fabulous! I am looking forward to get the other sets as fast as I can.

positive:
1. many shields and specific viking equipment
2. perfect longship design (from the bow to the tail with the enormous sail)
3. the price per brick ratio is the best in the viking-series
4. nice construction: midgard-snake

negative:
1. How could Lego forget about the rear-rudder? 6057 had one!
2. less bonus equipment (then in earlier sets)

I hope that Lego will hold up to this series. And maybe they could introduce some more Viking-Enemies (more realistic ones, like battles against the british island, etc.)

author: omgbrick
title: sweat serpent
review: This sety is a good set with high playabilty since it comes with both 6 vikings and a fairly sizeable serpernt (about the length of the ship). theres no purpose for the cage as some people have said the only things i found it could be was an exucatinon or sacrfice cage maybe an elevator if the captain is lazy the ship has tons of room to store many other warriors or cargo. the sove is cool and lego ndid provide keg of beer for any thirsty warriors the dragon head is made usinga new dragon head  black wings and a dark red wolf head. a very good set buy it.

author: brickzone
title: Well decked out
review:
I didn't believe this ship could be as good as it is - so I waited till getting a cut price one. But it is worth every cent of the full retail price.

* The scale - I did not realise that not only is this ship wide-hulled, but has three mid-sections between the two end pieces.

* The Vikings - These guys are awesome, each with its own colours and individual dress, but yet they look like a coherent Viking horde! I love the mottled metal effect helmets, armour and axes.

* The Serpent - This is a seriously involved construction with the sections articulating up and down as well as revolving - there's some kind of clever ratching to allow set positioning of the sections; they stay in place when positioned. The pieces are useful for anything from little boats to space ships, and the creature is some size as mentioned by others.

* The sail and look of the ship - The sail is gigantic, must be the biggest ever. The ship passes off well as a longship due to the look of the sail, size of ship, shields along the sides, tall prow/stern and the dragon figurehead and tall platform at the back. I love the details like the fireplace & chicken, weapons stands, beer/water tap on barrel, etc.

* Pieces - all manner of useful intricate little parts, it took an age to put together, have a look online at the part inventory! 40 white horns alone! The brown bits are great for customising too. The alternative idea on the instructions shows the versatility, using part of the ship sections for a port/dock/quay. There are a reasonable amount of minifig accessories

* Arrow launcher - perhaps not realistic, but a fun and mechanically good item!

Cons: These aren't enough to bring it down from a five in my opinion, you can easily add the features yourself: It'd be nice to have something more on deck; looking at drawings etc., I think you'd want a bigger canopy or "tent" than just the fireplace. There aren't enough Vikings to crew the ship really - I'll either get some more or use scurvy non-descript anonymous pirates - but I think maybe it really would have been the warriors doing the rowing to keep fit (plus would you waste space on just rowers?), so maybe it would be better if I can buy some Vikings on their own.

I'd like the Vikings to have some kind of human opposition, or just people to loot and pillage. Without these, there's no-where for the ship to go, and no-one to put in the cage. But I'll build something myself for now of course :) Maybe a round tower and monastary from some castle bits?

author: Jedi_Master_Fangorn
title: Turkey boat
review:
Great ship, this was the one set I was going to get from the Viking line.  Oh well, now I have 2 other sets besides this one.

The good:
- TURKEY!  The whole reason I bought the ship! (Okay, maybe not, but it definitely helped).
- HUGE sail
- really realistic turkey roaster 
- serpent
- interesting shooter-thing on the front
- dragon on front is pretty neat too

The bad:
- rudder, where is it?  A ship this size should have one.
- diving cage?  What is that doing here?

I gave it a 4/5, not a bad ship, and really the only one of any size since the Pirates sets.

author: Imperial13
title: COOL!
review:
This set in its box looks amazing! this set takes about 1hour to make. This set has a high playability value with the full crew of vikings to battle a serpent!  I took it apart after about 1 month to make the Merry-Go. the cage doesn't really work or have a purpuse. The sides of the boat are wobbly and the oars dont really work.besides the oars and cage it is a great set!

PROS:
serpent (good for creating battles)
a lot of vikings
base of the ship
gun thing (good to put on wheels)

CONS:
mast falls a lot
cage doesn't work well
sides of the ship are to loose and wobbly
 

most of all i think it should have come with a small dinghy!

author: Blade
title: Wow... Just plain Wow!
review:
This set truly is awe inspiring. This has to be the most reviewed model I have reviewed to date and I think I could write a book on it, but I wont.(Poor Verifiers)
Also it's hard to say what others haven't already said so maybe I will extend or add.

Well to put you in the picture the serpent and boat are approximately 48cm or 19" for you imperial people long and the boat is about that high as well. The sail spans just over a whopping 30cm or 12" or 1 foot. The detail in this model is quite extensive and well thought out. Plenty of room on the deck with the added bonus of food and drink.

Plenty of armoury on the boats outer and some massive fire power inside. A giant missile launcher aught to do the trick. Holding 4 missiles at a time gives that back up if you miss. I suppose this is better Than cannons and is trying to represent flaming arrows but obviously that would be too dangerous for a children's toy.

The cage is quite curious. It has multiple purposes and I feel they need to be explored.

Firstly - It's Not a diving cage to new age but dose bring about the possibility if something was dropped in the harbour it could be retrieved the water being shallow and all?
Second - An excellent way to move treasure or friend or foe off another ship?
Thirdly - How about instead of walk the plank, I just drown you? Works for a viscous viking, works for me.
Forth - Sacrifice to the serpent. Then he may ignore the boat?
Fifth - Lowered into the water at shoulder hight would make a convenient bath?

My best guess I feel is hold up a mutinous crew member or thief and or drowning him.

The amount of figs surprised me. Six all up so exclude your captain and captive your two ors short. If the captain rowed as well it would go off course so you let the captive row to make six? 

I think not he is more likely to attack the crew or if a serpent is chasing them he's thinking " Hmm, stay hear and get eaten, as we will never out row that or bail out now and hope to hell that the serpent is too distracted with them to notice me." Well that's how I would see it. So in my opinion, four rowers is correct, assuming the captain man's the gun for defences against the serpent.

Anyway onto the serpent. I feel its awesomely done made from lots of actual bricks so it looks like a Lego serpent, not a plastic moulded hunk of rubbish from MacDonald's. But seriously check it out for yourself its very intricate and very possible with a jaw that opens 90 degreases. 10/10 for the serpent.

Two small things - 1. Needs a rudder (Obviously Forgotten in 578 other pieces) 2. The mast is slightly wobbly due to its height but that's no biggy. 

Oh almost forgot the crane mechanism is brilliant. Its on a ratchet like a boat winch witch again shows the quality of this model

Well I think that is all that can be said. As a whole this set is a 10/10. Full marks and well designed. I think this set really shows the quality and ingenious ideas that we have all come to expect from such a quality company. Good Work!

author: Smallsam99
title: one word: AWESOME!
review:
This set rocks and I got it for only 39.99 at christmas time. I love the set and it yields lot of playability. I highly recommend it to any viking or lego fan!

pros: 5-6 vikings!

treasure box with 3 gems!

huge sail!

catapult!

roasting chicken device

sheilds! 

6 oars

cons: none


Buy this set even for 50.00 it is a good deal!

you wont be sorry!

author: Zac
title: Excellent idea, poorly realized
review:
The short-lived Viking line of 2005 and 2006 stands out for the novelty of its subject matter and for the strength of the prints and parts developed to enrich its historical setting, and less so for the design of its sets. 7018 Viking Ship challenges the Midgard Serpent offers the larger of the two longships developed for the line, the other being 7016 Viking Boat against the Wyvern Dragon. Judging by the other reviews, 7018 has been well-received, but it suffers from structural weaknesses and an overemphasis on its projectile system. Current aftermarket prices on Bricklink seem entirely disconnected from the set’s lack of merit.

 

The Vikings are remembered in the popular imagination for their longships and coastal raids, so I find it puzzling and frustrating that the Viking line was dominated by missile launchers, siege machines, and dragons. That the line’s largest set was 7019, an octagonal reiteration of Fort Legoredo, rather than a more fully developed longship was a missed opportunity. 7018 has the scale and ambition suitable for the largest set in a line, but appears to have been designed with the number of parts appropriate for a medium-sized set.

 

Bounty of parts . . .

The longship’s hull consists of five pieces: two identical pieces double as bow and stern, with three middle sections. The middle sections are the same as those used for pirate ships, but the bow and stern were developed specifically for this set. They appear in two subsequent sets in different colors, but were only available in reddish brown in 7018. The two sections of 7018’s mast are the 2004 mast patterns, rather than the older classic Pirates designs, and are unique in this set in tan. Relative to their predecessors, the 2004 mast patterns are markedly structurally inferior and cannot be readily attached in a sturdy manner to each other or to anything else.

 

Other new pieces and prints include the massive, stiff cloth sail; the Viking helmet; the white horns mounted on either side of the helmet; the axe heads; and the shields mounted on the side of the longship, printed with four varied patterns. The hand-held shields use stickers. The large oars—four in dark green and two in reddish brown—are an unusual treat. The speckle black-silver plastic used for the helmets and the axe heads was, I believe, new in 2005 and must have been developed for the Viking line. Each of the six Vikings sports a new torso print, which are beautifully detailed, and some of them have new heads. Much of the set’s attraction comes from these new pieces, prints, colors, and re-colors.

 

. . . but poverty of design

The design of the longship compares favorably to historical models, with its banks of oars, side-mounted shields, and single large square sail. Relative to the ships represented in the Pirates line, longships had relatively flat hulls and would seem to be inherently more suitable for representation using Lego because they conceal a smaller portion of their bulk below the waterline.

 

The parsimony of the designer in holding together the longship’s five hull pieces, however, results in an unstable model prone to breaking apart. Each pair of hull pieces is held together with two 2x4 bricks on the bottom and a single brick, usually a 1x6, on the top. The clutch power of the bottom of the hull pieces is less than usual, and if one were to attempt to pick the longship up from one end or the other the it would fall apart. Similar problems plague the dark red decorative upper continuations of the hull fore and aft: these will fall off or break apart at the slightest touch. The two sections of the mast, by their very design, cannot be easily secured either to the deck of a ship or to each other. In 7018, the sail can easily topple over, or the mast break in half or disconnect from the hull. Structural failures abound in every aspect of the longship’s design, and its so obviously uncovered hull pieces lend the set an incomplete quality.

 

Other aspects of the longship have more to recommend them. Around the mast stand a firepit with poultry roasting on a rotisserie under a striped awning, as well as a keg of what is no doubt water. The winch mechanism mounted on the mast works well. The missile launcher is indestructible and, as I recall, effective. It uses one of the springy minifigure mounts designed for the Soccer line. The red dragon head that ornaments the prow of the ship creatively uses a second molded head as its lower jaw. I had and have no interest whatsoever in the so-called Mitgard Serpent, but it is structurally sound, highly articulable, and can fit a minifigure in its jaws.

 

Play value

No doubt many children playing with 7018 enjoyed launching missiles at a watery serpent, but my play was and is less projectile-oriented and I quickly removed the launcher. Without what was clearly intended as the set’s primary play feature, it offers fewer play possibilities. The rotisserie and the winch are enjoyable, and the chest of blue gems gives the Vikings something to dispute, but the longship itself requires structural reinforcement before it can be used in a robust manner. Moreover, it offers fundamentally the same play experience as nearly every other Vikings set, which feature similar projectile launchers mounted on ships, wheels, or fortifications. Such robust projectile launchers appear to have been de rigueur in 2005; note them on the contemporaneous Dino Attack line’s jeeps, tanks, and helicopters.

 

Compare 7018 to its smaller counterpart, 7016, which consists of two rowboats joined stern-to-stern and connected by a mast and a piece of string. 7016 is a gem of a set, suggests classic Castle design, and produces a more distinctive longship profile, largely due to the string. Play with 7018 is directed towards the projectile launcher; play with 7016 is open-ended and encourages imagination.

 

7018 offers a promising idea and excellent parts but a poor design, apparently the result of piece constraints and an insistence on the elaborate projectile launcher and serpent. Two stars.

author: rabk295
title: Totally Wicked Dude!
review: This set is by far my favorite boat set. I forget what I got it for, but I am glad I told my mom to get me this instead of an Exo-Force tank thing. I have had much fun with this set. The sail is incredible (Size and cool art). I also enjoy the Firing mechanism which is unrealistic, but it is a great play feature. The cage is also a cool idea. I enjoy making up characters and putting them in the cage to play with. The fire and spit are one of the coolest designs by LEGO I have seen so far. I also added some things to the set such as an oar holder for when all of the vikings need to fight. Some of the small bad things are the mast (it sometimes breaks)and the firing mechanism (somtimes the missles only go 2 inches or they don't fire at all), but don't let that get in the way of your fun. This is an awesome set overall, and if you get the chance to buy it any where, you should definately buy it.

author: theL
title: cool
review:
this set is very good. I got this set one year for chrismas from my parents at my uncles. unfortinatly, the dog chewed it up. stupid dog. but luckely, my other uncle got me the same set. soo i had two of these and the chewed one i took off the bitten parts and added my own lego collection to make a pirate ship. on with the pros and cons:
pros

cool loking

cannon thing fire's well

snake looks cool

preety much every thing else.

cons 

nothing

this is a very good set and if you get two, use YOUR lego collection to make your own ship.

author: Matthew91294
title: Great Ship
review:
The Viking Ship is a very cool ship. Not only does it come with six minifigs, but it also has a lot of room on deck.

   pros:
   6 minifigs
   sea serpant
   launcher
   extended oars
   HUGE cloth sail
   three shields, six weapons
   chicken roaster
   cage
   weapon and shield storage

   cons:
   none that came to mind

I have probably played the most adventures with this set out of all my collection.

author: braycraft
title: ONE OF THE BEST LEGO SETS EVER!
review:
One comment:

 

BUY THIS SET!

 

The only problem with it is the missile launchers... but what were Vikings launching missiles for anyway?  Take it off, and look at a phenomenal set!

author: jeroenaa95
title: very cool set!
review:
I bought this set in The Netherlands in 2006. I have paid €60 for this set. I love the large ship and giant seasnake. There are 6 vikings in this set. On the boat there is a catapult to shoot the giant snake. I think this is a nice set for only €60. The troll boat from castle is €80, and that boat doesn't come with a giant snake. The small boat of the vikings is a nice extension too this set. Now on to the pros and cons.

 

Pros:

- Giant snake!

- Large boat with a catapult.

- 6 vikings: 1 viking leader with a gold tinted helmet and sword, 1 viking who shoots the catapult, 1 viking with a large axe, 1 viking with a silver tinted sword, 1 viking cook and 1 viking with an armorplate and a small axe.

- Fireplace by the mast.

- Large sail with a snake on it.

 

Cons:

- If you have all the viking sets, like me, you don't have enough space to place them all. That isn't nice.

- should have been little more expensive, with more vikings. (my opinion)

 

Overall it is a nice set with a lot of detail, like the shields on the side. If you like the viking sets, you should be this set.
